page.title: 17FORTH AND CLYDE CANAL
page.content: Construction began on the Forth and Clyde Canal in June 1768. The main problem was the Dullatur bog. It had to be drained using ditches which led into the Bonny Water and the River Kelvin. The total cost of the canal was Â£330,000. This was much more than the estimate of Â£147,337. In 1812 there a passenger service began on the canal running from Glasgow to Edinburgh. In 1893 day trips were started on a boat was called The Fairy Queen which was brought into operation by James Aitken. These trips kept up until the second world war. Nowadays the canal is used for pleasure and not for trade. Anglers enjoy the coarse fishing there and many competitions are held every year.
